name: Pentagonal tiling
rephrased: It is impossible to tile the Euclidean plane using regular pentagons.
implication_form: If one attempts to tile the Euclidean plane with regular pentagons, then it is impossible.
posed_by: No specific person, it is a known impossibility
explained: The conjecture states that a regular pentagonal tiling of the Euclidean plane is impossible. This impossibility arises because the internal angle of a regular pentagon (108°) does not divide 360° evenly, preventing the regular pentagons from fitting together without gaps or overlaps to cover the entire plane. While regular pentagons cannot tile the Euclidean plane, they can tile the hyperbolic plane (with four pentagons meeting at each vertex) and the sphere (with three pentagons meeting at each vertex).
